comments.commentBody:
"The United States said the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah has trained and advised government forces...."

Is this the same Syria with a military relationship with Russia, Russian air defense missles and Russian ships in their port?

Anyone advocating for more war, either enlist, take your children to enlist OR shut up and have some respect for the men and women whose lives have been irrevocably changed by cowards who are for war as long as other fools die
.
Keep your Walter Mitty rambo impersonations to yourself.
War is not a video game. There is no on, off or pause switch.

Our first prep school cheerleader, Vietnam avoider president, George Bush started two useless, insane, debilitating, bankrupting wars.

Now, another prep school cheerleader, VietNam draft dodger, from a family of zero veterans in five generations wants to send other peoples children to die.
Not only has his family never suffered, he may or may not even pay the taxes to fund it.

Yes he did a lot wrong. He stole another writer's words and claimed that were his own. When you use another writer's words directly you are supposed to attribute them to that writer and giver that writer credit.

Plaigirism is just another form of THEFT. So Zakaria is nothing but a thief by stealing from another writer's works and using them as if they were his own.

Is this the right way to look at it? The lady researched and wrote about a material which was otherwise unknown to Fareed Zakaria. Otherwise he wouldn't have used her own words. He took a free ride on her hard work and must now face the consequences.

I like Zakaria as well, but this was clearly plagiarism It wasn't a word for word copy, but the entire flow of the paragraph was identical.  All he needed to have done was to attribute the history to Ms. Lepore and there would be no issue.

I'm a big fan of Zakaria's so I hope this doesn't keep his voice out of the media for very long.  Truth to tell, I can't see that he did very much wrong here.  He's merely quoting an attributed source who was previously quoted elsewhere.  Big deal.  Does this suggest that I can't quote a passage from, say, the New Testament if it had been previously used within the context of another author's dissertation on theology?  "There but for the grace of"...aah, never mind.

USA was too much for Argentina...They were tto good. Specially Durant. I still believe this generation of players deserved a bit more...Ginobili is amazing. So are Scola and Delfino. These men play their heart out. They gave everything they had but it wasn´t enough..Hopefully they´ll get a bronze medal.

When the Ralph's here in Calfornia started their card scam in 1999, I walked out of their store and have never gone back.  I've never been inside the fairly new Ralph's that was built within a block of my house.  I've never been back to Von's, Albertson's or Rite-Aid.  Or CVS.
David Chowes: Mittzi doesn't drink beer (Mormons don't imbibe) but otherwise your point is well taken.
Wasn't he governor of Alaska or something?
Too good to be true! Ryan's choice will ensure Obama's re-election! He is the Koch Bros handmaiden with a congressional record lacking heart and compromise skills.
You read it here first: it's Joe the Plumber!

To be at peace among others is indeed a noble goal. But i disagree that, in general, hermits take the easy way out.

My hunch is that there is much more pain and hope behind each story than we might imagine and that living with the choice to be solitary takes much more courage and work than we in the world can understand.

Still, yours are good comments. And i'm glad the NYT printed the photos, the article, and the editorial comments. Thank you.

Dear Reader in Wash, DC.
You post implies that the victim somehow got what he deserved for being in this country illegally. How vile, racist, ignorant and despicable a comment. The victim was not an illegal. He was a human being.
That's a whole different issue -- generations of people living on inherited wealth.

@Laszlo---Although I agree with you about this puzzle, I don't agree that Mr. Lampkin's Friday puzzle was unworthy of publication in the NY Times. Although I cringed when I filled in ORIENTATED, after learning more about the word, I think it's fine as a puzzle entry. In any case, its appearance in the grid certainly led me to learn some interesting etymology.

No offense XwJ, but let us stay in our respective corners in this bout. I side with the majority of NYT readership, I believe, that finds the word indefensible. The other side including yourself and Will, begrudgingly accept it as a good enough puzzle word. This loosening of the standards is what leaves me bewildered. The NYT adheres to the highest standards in all other sections of the publication. Why make an exception here? Citing past occurrences of a crime doesn't make it any prettier.

Ultimately Will always wins, so there is no point in conversating about it any further. I accept his decision, but please also accept my vehement disagreement with it. I would've adminstrated it differently, but it wasn't my job. I only pray ORIENTATED will never show its ugly face again.

I absolutely loved this puzzle. The NW came rather easily, then the SW - with one error. NEFERTITI helped me crack the SE, then FLAREGUN the area just North of that. FESTIVUS, the holiday for the rest of us, got me settled in comfortably in the NE and soon I was done.

The sign of a good puzzle is that even seemingly uncrackable clues, like "Moon, in Chinese" (how am I supposed to know that?) eventually make total sense when you figure it out. The fact is, I did not remember how to spell CAP*BARA, even though I watch my share of nature shows on Discovery and NatGeo. I had CAPuBARA, but UIN did not look kosher. So I took out the U and stared at it for a while when it hit me: YIN! As in YIN and yang.

That was my one error.

My favorite feature of this puzzle: no ORIENTATED!

Kudos to Josh Knapp for a winner of the highest caliber, truly worthy of the New York Times, as yesterday's was not.
Because he knows full well that if he releases his returns he'll lose.

I'm really amazed that a guy like Romney would allow him to be damaged by this issue.  It's the summer, a slow news cycle with few paying attention. Instead of getting it done, he's letting it build up to a roar in September and October.

Mr. Stewart, wouldn't your article have been more accurate - or at least more complete - if you had more clearly stipulated that the "400" you wrote about averaged TEN TIMES the income cited for Mr. Romney in 2010. With that wild disparity between Mr, Romney's income v. Your "control group," doesn't it sorta make your entire article a waste of ink?  Also, it would have been helpful if you had remembered to include the fact that the Top 1% already pay almost 40% of all the federal income taxes in America. Further, are you suggesting that people - regardless of their income status - should not use the tax code to minimize their tax liability?  If so, the perfect vehicle already exists to resolve this question:  if you believe that the US government is a careful steward of your money, then you can and should voluntarily write a check to the US Treasury for more than your tax bill. Perhaps you should suggest that to the President as well. It seems like a simple solution. Thank you.
And they demand to balance the federal budget cutting grandma's meager social security pay check. This is a great country isn't it?

The rich may pay lots of money in taxes, but the country is running a deficit and Romney's party wants to fix it by taking money from Medicare, Medicaid, welfare, and anything that benefits the poor.  If we need more revenue, simple fairness decrees that it should be paid by those who can afford to pay it.  We should not try to balance the budget on the backs of the poor and the middle class.

This analysis is pretty sketchy. If you've ever lost money on the stock market--and face it, most of us have, then you have had capital losses.

Capital losses are real. That was real money you lost.

Thank God you get to net those losses against gains. That's not a sham, it's just fair.

I only wish we could net them against ordinary income. Waiting to get capital gains in recent years is like waiting for a miracle. In the meantime, we sit here with those useless loss carry forwards because we can't net the losses against ordinary income.

I was hoping this article would shed some real insight on how these people pay lower tax rates than I do. Capital losses is a bad explanation.

Is Romney's reluctance to release earlier tax returns because he took advantage of the IRS's amnesty program for individuals that claimed deductions for foreign investments that were found to be illegal by the IRS? Acceptance of amnesty for illegal activities would far more politically damaging than the disclosure that he legally payed no income tax for the years in question.
Please look up the term "red herring".

These Dems act as if the Reps are all rich and the dems just "getting" along.  How about Harry show how much is in his account(s).  And all the tax cheats in Obama's house! What about all his pals he brought in that have tax issues. Doouble standard as always with the Dems!!!!!!!!!!

If Rommney had not paid taxes then the IRS would be all over him! So who's playing politics? and macking a federal case over nothing. More diversion by the dems to keep focus off of the crap ecomony and printing machines at the Fed Res.

There are many in Canada, don't know about PQ, who legally do not pay income tax.  Perhaps the time is now exposed and both will work on the loopholes.  Some Canadians do all their entertaining, incl'g at home, as a write-off, buy the wine, pay the entertainment, etc.

My American Friends (I'm Canadian, eh):

You can talk all you want and cuss "The Mitt", but that's not going to do anything. If he did pay little tax, that's because the regulations and rules of the IRS allowed him to do so.

What you have to work on is getting the Democrats to keeping pushing their agenda, and showing how the "Mitt" party is all for themselves, and against the "little people".

Leona Helmsley summed it up best in her infamous quote: "We don't pay taxes. Only the little people pay taxes".

You have a choice to make: Believe all of the distorted and venomous hatred that the Republican party would have you believe, or believe what the Democrats have to offer.

Many of you do believe what the Republicans have to say, and many of you believe that the Democrats are liars and cheats, and purveyors of distortions and venomous
hatred.

May I suggest that you take a stronger interest in all that is said, printed, and discussed, and make a decision based on the facts, and not the "untruths" or half-truths. Because, this election is going to be a pivotal point in the history of the United States.

Your vote is important and you should vote based on the facts and your feelings of the facts.

I should know.

I live in Quebec, where there are 2 political parties who would have this province separate from Canada based on lots of "semi-truths". The current party in power is no angel and is not perfect, but the September 4th election will be an important one for all!
Excellent point!

When Mr McCain considered and then rejected Mr Romney eligibility as VP candidate, he had 23 years of tax returns before he would consider Mr Romney's eligibility to be VP.

The American electorate is just asking 10 years of tax returns of Mr Romney, for considering his eligibility to be President.

We do have a right and Mr Romney an obligation.

When Romney says he wants to broaden the tax base, I really doubt he means by eliminating shelters for the rich. What he means is a broadening out downward to tax more of the working class and the poor. This has been an explicit objective of the Republican Party for some time now.

In a famous thought experiment known as Schrodinger's Cat (fans of Big Band Theory know of which I speak), physicist Erwin Schrodinder explained that if a cat is put in a covered box with a vile of poison that the cat may or may not break, the cat might be dead, might be alive. But until you open the the box you can think of the cat as being both alive AND dead. Only when you open the box dod you get an answer.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schrödinger's_cat
The tax issue is vital. Isn't it utterly clear to everyone that Mitt Romney knows that if he releases his tax returns he will lose the election?

My first post-graduate degree Harvard M.Arch professional firm paycheck was minimum wage McDonalds burger flippin' finger lickin' good at $2.25/hour with 35% withheld for payroll, local, state and federal taxes.

That was disheartening 35 years ago, especially when my MBA, MD, and JD peers were pulling down four times that amount at half the tax rate with their employers' cooperation and consent.

Nothing has changed since then...they are all set to retire, if they have not already, while Architects now earn on average less than our much needed School Teachers and Professional Nurses.

Makes a person wonder, "What Was I Thinking?"

Architects? Weren't they extinct with the Egyptian pyrimids? (a comment I received on an airpane flight from a 20 something seat mate recently ;-) Wish it were so!

So, Mitt, my Harvard contemporary, fess up and tell us how, truly how, you do it... without even really trying?!?
I'd be fine with it if the "so-called" job creators were actually creating jobs. However, most of them think of their money as Monopoly money. The one who has the most, wins.
